en_second_half: Magyars conquered the country in the eleventh century they found the Huns settled in it. As he spoke, I found myself becoming more and more absorbed in the story he was telling, and I wrote on and on, hardly noticing the time passing. The phonograph was a wonderful invention, and I was grateful to Dr. Seward for introducing me to it. As the evening wore on, I found myself becoming more and more comfortable, and I began to feel a sense of relaxation wash over me. The sound of Dr. Seward's voice, and the soft scratching of my pen on the paper, were the only sounds I could hear, and I felt my eyelids growing heavy. I was just starting to drift off to sleep when Dr. Seward stopped speaking, and I looked up to see him smiling at me. El viejo les dio chelines y, como vieron que les había dado mucho, quisieron más todavía, pero el anciano agarró a uno de ellos por el hombro y poco faltó para que lo echara por las escaleras; entonces, todos ellos se fueron, insultándolo. He enters the room, a look of satisfaction on his face, and tells me that he has secured a sturdy carriage and three fine horses. We will set off immediately, he says, and I can feel a mix of excitement and trepidation as I prepare to depart. The Professor hands me a map, pointing out the route we will take, and I study it intently, trying to commit the twists and turns to memory. As we prepare to leave, I notice a group of locals gathered outside, watching us with a mixture of curiosity and suspicion. The Professor notices them too, and his expression turns serious. "We must be careful," he says quietly. "We do not know what dangers lie ahead." With that, we climb aboard the carriage and set off into the unknown, the wheels creaking as we begin our journey. The Professor takes the reins, and I sit beside him, feeling the wind in my hair as we pick up speed. The landscape unfolds before us, a rolling expanse of hills and forests that stretch as far as the eye can see. I feel a sense of freedom, of adventure, as we leave Veresti behind and head into the heart of Transylvania. As the sun begins to set, casting a golden glow over the landscape, the Professor points to a range of mountains in the distance. "The Carpathians," he says, his voice full of awe. "We will be crossing them soon." I feel a shiver run down my spine as I gaze up at the towering peaks, their rugged beauty both captivating and intimidating. The Professor notices my reaction and smiles. "Do not worry," he says. "We will be prepared." But as the darkness gathers, and the shadows grow long and sinister, I cannot shake the feeling that we are being watched, that unblinking eyes are trained on us from the trees. I try to push the thought aside, focusing on the rhythmic clip-clop of the horses' hooves, but it lingers, a nagging sense of unease that refuses to be dismissed.

The sky was a deep, burning blue, and the sun shone with a fierce, red light, but there was no warmth in its rays. As we went higher, the air grew colder still, and the wind more bitter. I wrapped my cloak around me, and pulled my hat down over my eyes, but even then I could feel the icy fingers of the blast. I followed her, and we went on in silence, the only sound being the rush of the wind and the rustle of our clothes as we moved. As we climbed higher, the landscape changed, and the rocks became more barren and desolate. The trees grew smaller and more stunted, and the grass was sparse and coarse. I could see for miles and miles, and the view was one of the most desolate and awe-inspiring that I have ever seen. And yet, with all its bleakness, there was a strange, wild beauty about it, a beauty that seemed to call to something deep within me. I felt my heart stirring, and my senses quickening, as I gazed out at the vast expanse of the unknown. Suddenly, Madam Mina stopped, and I stopped too, for I knew that she had seen something. I followed her gaze, and then I saw it too - a great, dark shape looming in the distance, its outlines vague and indistinct. I felt a shiver run down my spine as I gazed at it, and I knew that we were approaching the very threshold of the unknown.
